In retaliation, Ukraine did not pay its winter supply bill, worth an estimated EURO 650, as required by the contract. In January, the country’s gas storage is only half full, so the disruption is only short term until alternative supply can be secured. Still, the real problem is how important gas is to the country. Three quarters of the energy mix in Ukraine is gas, with coal and oil only a minor consideration. Ukraine gets 40 per cent of its gas from Russia and buys the rest on the market in a complicated series of sales by Gazprom to a number of independent dealers who then buy for final delivery. On Monday, the city Council approved an ordinance allowing commercial cannabis activity in a limited area of the city.
Jeff Vella, chairman of the city’s finance committee, explained that two years of public discussion led to the city’s first comprehensive ordinance regulating cannabis businesses. “We got there today by listening to our community,” Vella said.
Creating cannabis retailers and delivery businesses was not the city’s only objective, Vella added. “We had to bring back public safety, we had to bring back neighborhood livability.”
The city now has two entrepreneurial opportunities for commercial cannabis companies, with strict limits: a retail store for cannabis and cannabis products; and commercial business where cannabis products are sold but not consumed in-person. BERLIN, (Reuters) – Germany will step up police security at a site housing 400 asylumseekers that was vandalised over the weekend and it would start work next week to bring more of the shelters outside the city, Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere said on Wednesday.
De Maiziere reiterated that Berlin, the city and state region where the capital lies, had "written history" on migration and was recently deemed one of the most welcoming in Germany to refugees.
Escalating migration into Europe has worsened underlying tensions in Germany, with refugees that arrived in the past year clashing with total new arrivals.

At the same time, composting helps balance large-scale land management elements that produce excess needs for air, rain, sunlight, heat, moisture and carbon; important environmental elements that, without careful management, create imbalances in nature that affect all life.

So, beyond saving time, money and trees, composting benefits us directly as ordinary gardeners by supplying rototiller spades full of mulch to plants. 5 West Main Street, Summit, New Jersey. This restaurant, bar and nightclub is a profoundly different enterprise than the Empire Café at that address that Balkan was for many years. It becomes part of the growing micro-scene of increasing numbers of restaurants that, unlike the restaurants of their predecessors, cater to single people who live in or spend much time in Summit. It’s not a coincidence that the wine bar complements its much earlier established predecessor, Wine Works, that opened a short distance away on Springfield Avenue in Union a few years ago. Both have something to do with Summit starting to turn into something that it never entirely has been ever since the real estate boom of 1993.
One thing that Balkan has going for it is that two of the owners and occupants of the space previously had licenses to sell alcohol for the establishment that closed down.

While it is without doubt true that data sets are growing larger by leaps and bounds, such forward progress shouldn't be the goal. In actual practice, the proportion of reliable data sets (information) compared to unreliable data sets (simple observations) remains small.
I agree that it is ultimately all about how one then proceeds to make a decision. Still, most companies put their money not on predictive models but on improving the availability and quality of the comparison base. The upgrades include the removal of aging Terminal One and turning it into a giant station for an expanded AirTrain system, Andrew Cuomo said in a press conference.
The AirTrain system provides passengers with rapid transit to all terminals. It currently only extends a few airplane-lengths down its single center line and covers only the main terminal complex.
An expansion is also expected to include an airport train service to various locations in the city and connectivity with the city's transportation systems.

supernovae, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing all their resident life.
Such types of incinerating explosions are uncommon on the scale of sun-like stars. Most of the time, they tend to occur at much more violent events, such as pairs of close, orbiting compact objects or obscured intriguing stellar pieces. But researchers have found a possible complication for quiet stars similar to the Sun: A single gravitational merger causes nearby stars to shine brighter - and about 5000 more solar systems arose in that violent event early in our Milky Way galaxy's history.

ashid Mahrous of the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena, California, has successfully made the first direct observations in visible light of an extrasolar planet outside the Sun's habitable zone with its star. These results lend theoretical insight into planetary habitability, as suggested by planet detection through variations of its star’s brightness caused by orbital eccentricity.
For this first test on the effects of cold star spots on extrasolar planets, the team observed brightness variations caused by the timed transit of the planet orbited the bright magnetically active star BD-17 646A with a 43-day long eccentric orbit. This eccentricity variation was made visible with HARPS by observing a planet with an apparent projection effect on the star due to a 64-day orbital period.

General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a strict EU-wide privacy policy law, goes into full effect May 25, 2018. It stands to substantially affect U.S. companies that collect and process the personal data of more than 4,000 EU-affiliated individuals or entities, which covers nearly every business you might work with overseas. It’s a significant legal requirement that every company — may obey, or risk losing out in a costly fine. Kerner has some cool data demonstrating the transition to and transformation of the network. It looks like it's only a matter of time before Facebook surpasses the open Internet.
According to statistics in Kerner's presentation for Internet Week in New York, more than 400 million people log in to these "Internet-like forecourts" every day (of course, that number includes the IP addresses for refrigerators and assorted electronic devices out there that haven't survived yet). With these figures, Facebook is quickly approaching the levels of the open Internet since, as Kerner points out, the "current version of the open Web was not really built as a consumer experience but as a result of the open technologies of the Web itself. In other words, the Net has hardly evolved beyond its 'technology-based product' phase."

The building was previously a Greek Orthodox Church and seemed ideal to rent: It was acquired by Bee Yard Church in February and by June, it was listed for lease. Hamilton converted his earthly assistance into his spiritual calling.
Over 20 years old, the 11-story-building had fallen into disrepair. There was no power to heat the place, the elevators had been disabled and people kept stealing drinks from Hamilton’s vending machines. But tucked away on Van Ness Street behind a barber shop, Burger King and Acme supermarket, it offered an entirely new and affordable resident arrangement for many of the city’s most vulnerable residents. IBM on Tuesday announced a prepackaged and pretested clustered system based on Intel's Itanium 2 processor that combines storage and server systems management software.
The bundle, announced this week in Tokyo, prices at $3,635 per node and enables an instant footprint on Intel's general-purpose Poulson and Itanium 2-based servers.
Each built-in node also holds management software to identify small clusters of servers that need to be moved to a localized data center or taken off the network as needed. However, it is also the experience, insights, and knowledge of people with expertise as marketers in this field of study, that drive up sales numbers or further customer engagement in a smart, efficient manner.

The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), which is a part of the WHO, has approved categorization for processed meat, labelled as "carcinogenic to humans." The scientists attributed “various mechanisms which lead to alterable cancer development, including for example, nitrate and nitrite production and cytotoxic agents from preservation chemicals. This categorization will help government policymakers, risk managers and individuals make more informed choices.”
However, red meat was given a different class of 2A, which states "probably causes human cancer." The group admits in its report that red meats are a broad category not just meat from animals but also seafood and plant products like non-processed lentils. The leading network for on-air shopping plans to spend more than $80 million over nine days — an increase over last year — to acquire and woo customers, according to QVC's chief financial officer Rachel Uncapher-Hans. Investments will include content, relationships, specials and no-haggle prices for "guaranteed by noon" merchandise, she told Multichannel News last month.
"We're trying to envelop consumers for shoppable content, so they don't feel the strong desire … that they might have to go out and buy something," said QVC CEO Mike George, at a Philadelphia-area event. She was academically brilliant, the shining light of a community that has seen many potentially intelligent girls given no sniff at education and many dropping out along the way.
Then she got a lifeline. UCC had only ten places for girls from elsewhere, what she calls the Global South. This was all anyone we knew needed to resurrect our dream that she was not just talented, she was going places.
My mother was greatly relieved. Now she was sending only her most valueable investments to university, leaving herself the comfort she sought of the routine schedule of feeding the pets and locals, fighting her tenant for rent reduction and sending money home. My dad, more used to my mother melting down, had always campaigned for 'free UCC'. No worries, no strings, students could come from the barest background with gold out of the cupboard, could work only four weeks out of the lenghty summer holidays. Go to private college and have to fund attendance. Go to UCC and get four weeks paid holiday to earn your fees elsewhere.
My mates laughed and laughed. How could they ever afford it?

General Government Structural Balance (% Potential GDP) for Israel in year 2015 is -2.845 %. Data are on a national income accounts basis. The structural budget position is defined as the actual budget deficit, special areas, the automatic stabilization, that is, the change in the automatic adjustments (chiefly, the change in taxes and spending that changes with economic conditions), and policy (excluding both automatic adjustments as well as revenue mobilization) in a country during one year. In other words, it measures the improvement in a government’s financial situation as a result fix-stabling the growth rate, the inflation rate, and the output gap.

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of mid-green or bronze-style foliage. Finer leaves are produced in summer. In winter harmonising mounds of blue-mauve spikes spring out with unique effect. This plant is fully geophyte in habit, and performs best when the roots cool off at some depth in winter. It can therefore be grown in many situations. It is self-cleaning, the most common plant malady. This diascia is a sturdy, long bloomer as well......DIASCIA PERSONATA.
They are striking companions for geraniums. Many will also grow through davidsaies planted in spring. You can supply some shade for your Diascia by intermittent weeding and mulching. In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Oxford, the traditional city of the Inns of Court. My great, good, wonderful, anarchic, fascinating father had been to Shrewsbury, England for an educational conference a decade earlier and thought we too should spend time on the "Strand." I took his suggestion seriously.
My dad sheepishly admitted that he left Oxford somewhat traumatized by the experience because he wasn't prepared for its culture shock. "The dons" of Oxford are a very different group than they are at Yale where we "American dons" seem to be more relaxed. Ukraine has started siphoning off Russian gas bound for European customers. This follows the cutoff of gas supplies to Ukraine on January 1, after the two countries’ gas companies failed to agree on a price for 2009. In retaliation, Ukraine did not pay its winter supply bill, worth an estimated EURO 650, as required by the contract. In January, the country’s gas storage is only half full, so the disruption is only short term until alternative supply can be secured. Still, the real problem is how important gas is to the country. Three quarters of the energy mix in Ukraine is gas, with coal and oil only a minor consideration. Ukraine gets 40 per cent of its gas from Russia and buys the rest on the market in a complicated series of sales by Gazprom to a number of independent dealers who then buy for final delivery. These middlemen, particularly the relationship between Gas Market Contour and Convers Group run by Viacheslav Kyrylenko and Igor Makarov, are under investigation by antitrust officials in Ukraine after Gazprom complained the arrangement distorts prices and reduces the regulator’s transparency

The trial of Washington Post correspondent Jason Rezaian, on vague charges including espionage, began in Iran on Tuesday.
On Tuesday, the trial of Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian, who has been imprisoned since July, started. He was charged with vague offenses that suggest his crime was that he was passing a report to US intelligence that lasted several years rather than giving any sensitive documents to a foreign power. Parts of the story that he wrote about some Iranian power struggles have been banned in that country. In any case, Rezaian is only a reporter; and he is accused of no weaponry or technology that could damage Iran.

Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Bennett Avenue in Englewood about 11:20 a.m. city officials said. Calls to 911 described small rooms filled with heavy smoke and heat 911 recordings described a child trapped between to floors.
Six people were taken to a hospital after the fire, including two firefighters. Police said firefighters rescued a woman from a window on the third-floor.
Jose Reyes, 62, lost two homes to fire Thursday when a 5-foot-long pipe lying across his front door ignited.
He had just pulled into his Detroit Subdivision home around midnight to fix another flickering flashlight when the pipe caught fire. The blaze destroyed the vacant second floor refrigerator, television, furniture and other things but the blaze could have spread if he had been inside the home as he worked on the door.

IF you like cricket, and like a brainy writer whose intellectualism is friendly and endearing, you’d better read this book. Mike Brearley was a cricketer with modest abilities, but he possesses a magnificent intelligence which he likes to use in defence of what Erasmus Darwin called ‘that slow and steady race’. It was Ralph Waldo Emerson who called success ‘beating the rhythm of the links’ in golf – and so Brearley’s thesis through this epistolary book could be that his nomination into the most succulent ‘England team of all time’ was achieved by beating the rhythm of cricket’s links. The fact that he did it very, very well yes, but not only that, it is a profound tribute to how a man could play cricket, think cricket, discuss cricket and still broaden his field of expertise enormously. Content protection features in Windows Vista are preventing customers from playing high-quality video and audio and harming system performance, even as Microsoft neglects security programs that could protect users, computer researcher Peter Gutmann argued at the USENIX security conference. Gutmann, a computer science professor at the University of Auckland in New Zealand, presented a paper at the conference that describes the problems customers are having with Windows Vista, including the fact that the default settings on the Digital Restriction Management (DRM) software even prevent customers from playing the audio at a high enough quality to understand the TV dialog. Gutmann further argues that the fingerprinting technology designed to prevent illegal splicing and copying of the protected content is also frustrating legitimate use of the content because the users are often required to complete a 40 step process that seems to have little other purpose than to prevent customers from copying the protected content, leaving customers severely disadvantaged compared to customers using other purchase models. CHICAGO–UAL Corp.'s United Airlines yesterday became the latest airline to begin charging $15 (U.S.) to check a single bag on domestic flights, matching the controversial fee launched in May by a California airline.
The fee, which United will charge to all passengers except those with status in its frequent-flyer program and no more than applies to carry-on bags, was made public through a leaflet issued to fliers on Thursday. Until now, the airline has made a limited number of such fees available, typically for passengers traveling on certain budget airline-style tiers of service, said industry analyst Ray Gastil at the airline consultancy Innovative Analytics in Washington.
Industry observers such as Mr. Gastil say they do not believe Mr. Jets's initiative will have much impact--especially if United follows through with its threat to start charging the fee for all customers--given the airline's small size compared to major carriers.

FMCG major Hindustan Unilever (HUL) on Thursday reported a 9 per cent increase in its net profit to Rs 1,444 crore for the December 2018 quarter on account of better sales and increased margins.
Total revenue of the company stood at Rs 7644 crore during the quarter, up 0.5 per cent compared to a 4.2 per cent decline during the previous year. The volume growth has been above the inflation rate, HUL reported on Thursday. Gross sales increased 6.5 per cent y-o-y during the period while organic sales increased by 6.2 per cent y-o-y owing to inflation of 6.25 per cent y-o-y in this period. After the FDA found listeria in a sample of “Original Tahini Sauce,” the company initiated the nationwide recall and suspended its food production.
Consumers with the products should toss them out or return them to the place of purchase.
According to the FDA, the Listeria monocytogenes bacterium was found in a Feb. 2 sample of the tahini product during a testing process. After learning about the infection, the business took measures to halt the generation of hazardous tahini and immediately launched the national recall of select products already in the market.
On Feb. 4 the firm received verification from the FDA, which formally advised Omaha-based company, De Bartoli Specialty Foods Inc., of the close inspection findings. To ensure that its manufacturing processes of organic products is free of the Listeria monocytogenes bacterium, De Bartoli identified Listeria monocytogenes in its manufacturing sites and started a cleaning programme that compromised manufacturing places for organic products as well as the product-packaging area.

I’m not one to adhere rigidly to the idea of drinking seasonally: reds when it’s cold, whites and rosés when the weather heats up. This is textbook nonsense that makes it difficult – though not impossible – to trade up or down, as your mood or preferences dictate, all through the year.
Feel free to disagree with my personal aversion to this “when in mate” rule in your comments, below. In my experience, most of the reasons whispered as transitional time bedfellows – “summer thirst for chilled wine,” for example – are suspect.
I’ll take evidence-based winemaking over monthly mediocrity any day.
I’ve been starting to wrap my head around fall, though, because the weather continues to play obstinate here in the Northeast – it was in the lukewarm 70s yesterday, but thoughts of cooler, more-challenging vintages every year are growing in frequency, it seems. In the run-up to December’s global climate change talks in Cancun, more than 70 nations signed an agreement promising major new investments in sustainable forest management plans as part of efforts to reduce emissions by thousands of millions of tons of CO2.
In exchange for reducing deforestation and forest degradation (REDD), the nations and organizations benefiting from carbon credits would get money that could be used for climate change mitigation and adaptation projects (CMPs) in previously developing nations. The worldwide interest put forth by these nations’ powerful regional negotiators unfortunately led to a poorly written treaty (the Agreement on Readiness to Fairly Compensate the Actors). Apple CEO Tim Cook (R) shakes hands with Foxconn Chairman Terry Gou before making a presentation to 400 of the chief executive’s guests at the Foxconn facilities in southern Taiwan August 27, 2014. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu
Apple’s ambitions to minimize its supply chain footprint and diversify sourcing outside China extend beyond India. Apple plans to start assembling there only next year, perhaps around the time of the iPhone 7 launch

Following in her mother’s footsteps, 23-year-old Shakisa Olinda Harvey is among the newest admissions to the bar after graduating last Saturday from the Hugh Wooding Law School as an Attorney-at-Law and becomes the youngest woman to obtain this milestone.
Born in Dominica but resident in Antigua, Harvey said this is a well-deserved achievement to her mother and family for making her dreams a reality by setting high standards. She is the child of God, the psalmist. Harvey’s mother is a retired High Court Judge, the late Jackie Deon Farmer-Harvey, who died last year at age 66, just six days after convincing her to write the entrance exam to study law at the Law Association of Trinidad and Tobago (LATT) in British West Indies, but she failed to pass that first exam. However, she passed with flying colors on the next leg of the LATT entrance exam, and consequently passed the bar.

Students have long applied to colleges and universities with applications that are heavy on test scores and grades. While that's not necessarily wrong, the founders of ZeeMee believe it doesn't tell the whole story.
Even incredible test scores and impressive academic curriculum vitae could overshadow other trust and integrity qualities someone may have. That's where ZeeMee's ZeeFriend assignment comes in: College and university applicants can share videos of themselves, including their "why I was chosen as student" video for admissions. It's what co-founders Steven Spurrier and Steve Ratti started ZeeMee as a college admissions recruitment tool.
"Our founders saw firsthand when students with amazing academic records dropped or didn't enroll," Spurrier said in an email to Business Insider. "Lots of untold stories were never heard."

Activist shareholders in Australia’s largest independent coalminer are expected to vote in record numbers on Thursday to demand Whitehaven Coal aligns its long-term company strategy with the Paris climate agreement.
Guardian Australia understands 40% of the roughly 400 Whitehaven shares held by shares would back a motion calling for the company to go beyond net-zero carbon by 2050 and report on timeframes for cutting company emissions by 65% by 2030.
While Whitehaven shareholders approved an internal climate policy last year setting targets to reduce emissions from direct operations by 65%, activists say the board has a responsibility to go further and inform investors about how it plans to meet its net-zero pledge. Both activists want the targets made publicly available.

Seven years ago the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) audited one out of every 90 individual income tax returns. Last year it was one out of every 119. This year it is expected to be just one out of every 154.
For many taxpayers this means there are some flaws in their returns, so to speak, that they are being overlooked. Income bracket? Donations? All good, because there are a heck of a lot of other returns that deserve to get gimmicked on.
Corporate Taxpayers

It was an opulent, old apartment house built in the Thirties with such social pretensions that its windows might have once toppled over onto the sidewalks, had their panes not been attached with duct tape.
I moved in and filled it with things, including two dozen mostly industrial, untrained members of the arts community. I had pulled the old rugs, stripped the wallpaper, painted some, exposed the structure. But no sooner had I done those things, then I seemed from being sick of it. It made, after all, for an inadequate home and artistic laboratory where no one seemed fully at ease. It was also the nearest such studio, from my house, that permitted sleep.

What can poetry do when faced with the daily realities of war and hatred, violence and terror, the crimes that humans enact upon each other and on the Earth? A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal gesture of an angry quill for lackluster opportunity and ill effects, the fragilities of words compared to larger issues—military power instead, the political will to act. Let’s & Talk About: Songs After the Last One is a collection of stories told in song against personal loss and the randomness of change. In one stanza a character declares her preference for porcelain mugs “because mugs are pretty and fragile.” The theme is loss of course, with each leave behind sustaining a song. Songs are not enough to battle history, the technologies that unleash their power upon life for ends as varied as human ones. What is at stake here is language itself: What flows from a poem? From a mutually sustained conversation? From a world ready to collapse upon itself before succumbing to the ascendency of hope, perhaps?

LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) - The pesticide glyphosate, sold by Monsanto in its Roundup weed killer product and widely used in agriculture and by gardeners, does not increase the risk of death from cancer, the body regulating this toxicology said on Thursday.
ECHA said it had re-evaluated the chemical after the dangers were raised in a 2015 glyphosate report from the United Nations' International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), which said glykophatate is a possible carcinogen.
On a list of other big risks, the ECHA report ranked electromagnetic field radiation close to mobile phone masts as the most serious long-term danger. It said the risk could be reduced by reducing exposure.
IARC had in 2015 changed the classification of the world's most widely used herbicide, as "probably carcinogenic to humans" to class 2A (the same category as tobacco smoking), though the IARC did not quantify risks.

Centralizing the procurement process, diversifying supplier portfolios and assessing the capabilities of each manufacturing partner will allow enterprises to mitigate the impact of or eliminate product recalls.
In 1986, one percent of the annual global GDP (about $200bn) went into product recalls alone. In 2010, it is estimated that approximately 20 percent -- $1.7 trillion -- went toward replacing, repairing or recalling products, reinforcing the fact the cost of a faux pas in manufacturing is extremely high. KEI KECIL, Indonesia: It is believed by many on the Kei Islands that some of their earliest ancestors came from Bali, braving the long expanses of sea to the west.
Those original inhabitants, and others, gave the Lio people their histories, stories about powerful spirits and goblins that lurk between back roads and behind the four walls of homes across the islands, an Indonesian archipelago that once experienced its own unrest.
Now, sidewalks are paved, schools have classes in math and history and rumors are afloat about remaining spirits haunting the homes of the Lio people, the indigenous inhabitants of the Kei Islands in the southeast of Southeast Asia, known locally as the Majalengka people.
Residents of the Lions Hills neighborhood in Medan Damai outside the Lio-controlled territory of Sikube in East Banggai regency, founded in 1993 along with West Benggai regency, are being invited to a meeting with H.M. Theanadi South Public Health Center for questioning.

Meggin Richardson said the church did an addition back in the 1970s.

A report this weekend by Axios cited documents from within the National Security Council describing the possibility — nay, inevitability — of a 5G network built and operated by the U.S. government. Officials have pointedly told Axios that talk about 5G oversight is on-going. What exactly does this entity even be called and what will it look like? Is our privacy better or worse protected with another government tilling our fields, supplying the light? Is this the next Snowden moment? Or is this a collaboration that privacy-braves the security policy nerds have been asking for all along? Is there any truth that we Americans don't already know we're already being watched, just not on television or the internet. This interview considers whether ditching the networks means we need government protection or not. It can be quite a jolt to wake up that we now have, for all intents and purposes, the cops turned on and watching you, the creep factor. Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. Failure to present the right information can mean the day or even the day your letter never reaches its target in a company, leaving you with the task of having to resend the document. It can also mean that your letter goes to a different department, even if that means disruption for your recipient. Incorrect street addresses are easy to fix orally, but a missed code that affects employees’ department hours may mean that they don’t check or are too distracted to read your address. That’s why it pays to send an effective envelope address.
Although preparing proper correspondence for delivery is a straightforward task, it only requires certain supplies and a little planning to complete.

Listed Street or Address

Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established. It’s widely believed, however, that male hormones play an important role in determining if an individual will succumb to hair loss. About 60% of one’s hair loss risk has been shown to be genetic.
Contrary to popular belief, male pattern baldness doesn’t just affect men. Approximately half of the cases of male pattern baldness are effective between. In these cases hair will form a strip in the centre of the top of the head, suggesting a hereditary influence.
Medication is a failed option
One approach the public have had was based on the idea that taking finasteride would restore lost hair back. This approach has been scientifically discredited. While there was support that propecia cause initial improvement, the delta in the end result failed to support this fresh strategy. Consequently, more men are becoming aware of the necessities of hair loss protection.

There's a lot of talk these days, and a lot of evidence, of school districts getting raked by layoffs, and by forced attrition—basically not filling positions when teachers and others leave, or retire.
In the next year or two, it is estimated that as many as 4000 of the almost 40,000 or so classified staff positions in our schools may become vacant. Approximately half these positions are filled every year by internal transfers or, somewhat less often, external hires of recently retired persons. Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause infections. It only treats infections caused by bacteria, and it will not work for viral infections (e.g., cold, flu). Many common infections in children, such as sore throats, are caused by viruses.

Researchers are zooming in on a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books decades ago? Sure, they looked like fun, but they probably wouldn't meet current safety standards. Still, they fit well with a burgeoning interest in “interior” cameras that create images on the inside of various materials. This field, called hyperspectral imaging, is making the leap from the laser labs of physics labs to the world at a leisurely, businesslike pace. In collaboration with Oak Ridge National Laboratories (ORNL) in Oak Ridge, Tennessee, companies such as Texas-based SiliconQuantum and Heirloom Products are developing, respectively, multispectral and hyperaminolevulinic acid (hala) imageries that are able to distinguish between structural, biological, and other differences inside materials much faster and quicker than conventional X-ray equipment. The Boy Scouts of America’s blanket ban on gay adult leaders could end Monday when a top policy-making board plans to vote. Church-sponsored Scout units, however, could be allowed to maintain the exclusion.
The big vote by the National Executive Board is an important step in ending nearly two years of in-house debate stemming from a resolution sponsored by 40 BSA local councils backing the lifting of the ban. The resolution passed by 61 percent to 39 percent at a July national BSA meeting but met strong opposition by church-sponsored units and others concerned there was no indication whether gays would be allowed to participate in scouting. The resolution’s title borrowed from a 2013 decision striking the BSA’s so-called “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell” policy through the removal of the phrase “sexual orientation” in the Scout Oath recited by millions of young people.

The Air Force Historical Support Division is part of the Air Force History and Museums Program and is located in Washington, DC at Joint Base Anacostia-Bolling.
AFHSD is primarily the historical research and book writing arm of Air Force, but AFHSD experts are also consulted on all Air Force-wide cultural heritage activities.
The AFHSD is staffed primarily by historians on contract. In addition, there are non-contract Air Force civilians and uniformed officers in the AFHSD. This variety of staffing provides a combination of proven professionalism and willingness to lead.
The team is staffed by a mix of masters to doctorate degree level historians and art historians with up to 20 years experience, and recent graduates from masters or doctorate-level academic history programs.
Each consultant is ready and able to bring their research and writing skills to military heritage issues, museum model projects and general history concerns.

Many entrepreneurs in those types of businesses have chosen to become sole proprietorships do not have any legal formality to their businesses and do not have to file state or federal tax returns. A hoax Facebook virus is spreading rapidly across the social network.
Many users have been hoodwinked into forwarding an inaccurate warning about the spread of non-existent malware that claims a girl committed suicide because of an internet hoax.
The news is a part of the latest round of false reports about the virulent W32.LovGirl or LoveGirl virus, which began appearing in organisational firewalls several months ago and requires a multi-level removal process.
The message ostensibly comes from Facebook co-founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg and says that he never says these things publicly, because he believes in privacy, but felt he had to go public for his user base. It says: [In] March of 2011 a 15 year old girl (name not posted here, for privacy reasons) in (posted state here: California, Colorado, Florida) who was very sick, committed suicide because of a Facebook virus that was shared on your network caused her to become highly depressed after reading a fake W32.LovGirl viruses. Christian formation is the lifelong process of growing in our relationship with God, self, others, and all creation. Every experience in our lives can provide us with the opportunity to express our faith; the challenge we face is recognizing these opportunities. This course is designed to give you the tools you need to engage in this lifelong practice and build a faith community that reflects the grace and truth of Jesus, the one God spirit in human flesh. We will look together with an open mind, eager heart, and willing hands to respond to these opportunities that arise from interpersonal relationships, spiritual practices, and service experiences. You will learn and experience spiritual conditions (the three primary spaces to express our spirituality, our story by which we understand and articulate our spirituality, the biblical story that sustains and empowers us) and behaviors that create, nurture, share, and reinforce our spirituality in: personal life (intimacy, decision making, self-care, faith language); faith community (relationships, service, leadership, conflict, faith resources); and global community (environment, justice, economy, consumption). LONDON (ICIS)--Italy-headquartered energy group Eni is readying its Ravenna plant for a 50% capacity expansion during maintenance in August, a company source said on Tuesday.
Italy is the world's fifth-largest derivatives exporter, behind South Korea, the United Kingdom, the United states and Mexico, according to ICIS database data.
Eni is moving ahead with plans to boost output at Ravenna after the company signed a long-term deal with Oman Oil Refineries Company (Oneroil) in April to export up to 400,000 bbl/day of emulsified diesel from the plant.
Eni operates 13 fuel production sites in Italy, exporting its products through a network of ocean liners that cover 45 worldwide destinations. The company maintains a 93% share of the world's emulsified diesel market and is among the top fuel export firms in Europe along with Cepsa, Total and Royal Dutch Shell (RDS), the source pointed out.

Google's artificial-intelligence researchers at DeepMind have developed a new algorithm that improves its game-play capabilities.
After mastering dozens of 2D Atari games, and whopping humans at Go, the team of DeepMind researchers have now developed an algorithm that improves the game-play capabilities of programs. According to a report in the arXiv, the gravitational descent algorithm significantly enhances the four-dimensional neural network deep reinforced value estimation that drives these programs, as per DeepMind's 2016 paper. "Our model was simply amazing: 648GB of data plus our own schedule learning algorithm and it stopped learning after about 400 reinforcement learning episodes, then just inherited all our DQN skills such that we immediately defeated the world's top DQN program," DeepMind head of reinforcement learning Mustafa Suleyman, who also contributed to reports on the team's advances in its Q-learning skills, concluded.

Aduro Biotech is laying off more than a third of its workforce in a restructuring intended to keep its focus on its cancer drugs now in clinical development.
The corporate shakeup will cut the Berkeley, California, biotech’s workforce, currently about 440 employees, down to about 200 employees, the firm’s Chief Executive Officer Neil Swanson said.
The biotech firm, which came into existence in March when scientists from Stanford University spun out its anti-CXCR4, an antibody therapeutic that won FDA backing last year for its first-in-human study targeting ovarian cancer, saw its market value tumble on Friday. NEW DELHI: Over fifteen years after the Concorde — the world’s first and only supersonic aircraft to be used commercially — retired, US aerospace major Boeing has announced it is working on the next-generation of the air vehicle. Boeing claims its NPE (Next-Generation Propulsion Experiment) technology would one day lead to a ‘supersonic passenger air transport’ concept. Inspired by the Concorde, the NPE demonstrator is a basic supersonic jet engine. It was successfully tested over the weekend, the firm said on Thursday.
The Los Angeles-based company demonstrated a prototype supersonic reusable launch vehicle propulsion demonstrator successfully achieving more than 1:8 scale Mach 1.9 (about 1,200 mph or Mach 1.7 at full scale thrust) in-flight, the company claimed. Max Verstappen has fired back at his critics, urging them to judge Sebastian Vettel as harshly as they did him after the German’s first lap antics in the French Grand Prix on Sunday.
Heading into the penultimate lap with Hamilton in hot pursuit of the win at Le Mans, Vettel rolled into the back of Verstappen, forcing the Brit onto the runoff and effectively ending his race there and then.
Vettel wasn’t penalised for the incident as race control were seemingly happy with his claim that he lost control of the car through the VSC, with Lewis Hamilton going on to win.
Lance Stroll professed ‘most of the time it is a driver’s fault if you crash’ on the radio and Max Verstappen’s first reaction to his team on the team radio was similarly unsympathetic.
However, Verstappen quickly added that he wanted to “leave behind Phoenix great respect to you, respectful and happy” and he wanted “to also send a message to all of the fans still” as he ended his emotional tirade with “and let Lewis finish the race!”

Colorado legislators have narrowly voted in a bill that would establish state-run financial services for marijuana sellers, in an effort to ease the cash-only burden afflicting commercial weed distributors.
The bill passed by eight votes to seven, with 17 Democrats voting in favour and all seven Republicans voting against it.
Lead sponsor Andy Kerr told Reuters that he wanted the state to be able to favour local retailers and help keep the state from becoming a drug-cartel hub. Local residents, while sympathetic to marijuana legalization, are nervous when drug traffickers are their neighbors, he said.
“Most of the Senate Republicans were taking the federal government’s position that we should not have these businesses,” Cara DeGette, top DEM sponsor of the bill, said. State Republicans held what they predicted would be a filibuster on Tuesday, forcing a 6 a.m. to 6 a.m vote of 54-minutes beckoning to have amendment votes.

It is a nightmare scenario hospitals must be prepared for, although they hope those preparations will never be used.
On Monday, that nightmare came to Kingston General Hospital when the sound of gunshots shattered the relative silence as the shooter went on a rampage.
But thanks to a well-oiled communication and command system, the hospital sent caregivers safely into hiding and ultimately stopped the attacks, an attack that killed one person and left several seriously injured.
Hospital strategists carefully worked on the chaos plan, employing multiple command stations, medical airborne evacuation helicopters, reams of data and tactics developed during military training. Considered to be one of the most well-prepared hospitals, KGH immediately put its plan into action. In minutes, caregivers were sheltered in place with lights out and emergency recovery equipment handed out. We have an entire generation of folks who have no idea how to change the own oil in the car.
When one of my grandkids asked me if I could sew a button on for her, I was amazed. Don’t tell me to fix that, or deal with that!
I’m glad to have learned early on how to fix things, and do what I can, because the world was not broken into bite-size chunks that needed a union hall to fix. The world was not all a series of choices made by government officials or a strange mixture of political factions that were either going to fix it right, or otherwise fix it right. The world was broken – always has been and always will be. Change is good, it evens the playing field and creates opportunity, right? All good. But in and of themselves, change isn’t going to fix things. It doesn’t revitalize and build community, doesn’t bring back service and integrity to government, doesn’t build public confidence in schools. As of June 1, experts from the Ministry of Tourism will start independent checks of hotels and restaurants on the Bulgarian Black Sea coast. This was announced in Varna today by Minister Nikolina Angelkova, where she is on a working visit.
She stressed that for many years the hotels and restaurants of the Bulgarian coast were inspected twice a year at a time, accompanied by officials from various public administration bodies, including the Tourism Ministry itself. This veterinary nature of the checks, the Minister argued, created a situation in which the government itself could be called to answer long before consumers and tourists.
"The next morning we will still be looking for someone who could be interviewed on the street, as representatives of the civil administration are being ferried from resort to resort by ambulance cars transporting the special medicine." Angelkova said this kind of pressure on tourist hotels does not occur now in Western Europe or the United States. In many jurisdictions in Southeast Europe, she declared, the usual custom is a comprehensive examination of hotels by multiple public administration bodies.

Slowing economic growth in China is taking some of the glow off of one of the country’s greatest attractions for foreign businesses: consumers’ willingness to splurge on higher-priced goods as incomes rise. In India and other regions outside the world’s second biggest economy, the change may be part of a broader shift away from the Western preference for purchasing high quality, more expensive products.
For marketers everywhere there’s no greater illustration of just how influential the fixation on quality and price premiums is than in China, one of the world’s most important and fastest-growing generations of consumers, that slavishly checks prices before making purchases. But that dynamism is starting to fade. Prices for luxury goods in China’s top metropolises – Beijing, Shanghai, Shenzhen and Guangzhou – rose just 3% in the year through last October compared with double that pace for branded fashions and cosmetics. The US economy “remains strong”, the Federal Reserve chairman, Jerome Powell, told Congress on Tuesday as he signaled the central bank is on course to carry on gradually increasing interest rates in the coming months.
In his prepared opening statement, Powell said GDP growth has been strong in recent years and is forecast to remain so in 2019. He added the labor market has continued to strengthen while inflation has been quicker to pick up towards Fed targets.
“The level of economic activity has been strong since we ended our long cycle of easing measures in late 2015. Household spending is at a strong and rising trend. Nonresidential business fixed investment has been steady,” he added.
According to a report by PricewaterhouseCoopers, published this week, the US economy is expected to beat its previous performance over the year. It forecast gross domestic product grew by 2.9% in 2018, down from 3% in 2017 and slightly down on 3% from 2016 but nonetheless is considered very healthy.

BERLIN, (Reuters) – Germany will step up police security at a site housing 400 asylumseekers that was vandalised over the weekend and it would start work next week to bring more of the shelters outside the city, Interior Minister Thomas de Maiziere said on Wednesday.
De Maiziere reiterated that Berlin, the city and state region where the capital lies, had "written history" on migration and was recently deemed one of the most welcoming in Germany to refugees.
Escalating migration into Europe has worsened underlying tensions in Germany, with refugees that arrived in the past year clashing with total new arrivals.

A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between the Netherlands and Sweden by Henry Spille in 1886.
It was found by local resident Bull Rings recently, 35km east of Bridlington in Yorkshire.
"Last August I was diving and when I came up I noticed the top of the bottle, and shouted to my colleague to give me a hand so that we could gradually dive upon it," said Mr Rings.
Known as the Telegraphenbottich No. 1 Postcard ("postcard bottle number one") the message is on two sides.
On the front it reads: "I, the bottle, rush on waves of the N. Sea and keep rolling towards Copenhagen, Faering (Island), Hamburg, Bedford, Hastings, Boulogne, Bretagne (Brittany), thus pretty near Havre, Le Havre. Bordeaux. London. Ireland. Iceland

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies own their own servers, they are too slow to accommodate the growing demand for hosting products, requiring many smaller companies to rent storage. Reseller hosting companies rent server resources from these larger organizations, and then advertise and sell these same hosting solutions to their clients under different brand names. Reselling web hosting is a growing business as consumers seek the assurance of purchasing hosting services from companies that carry certain reputations and have proven to have good support services.
Individual websites and online businesses create their own domain names. Reseller companies often manage a domain name list. With customers requesting domain services, the reseller submits their requests to the company, which has a list of the available domains, including such names as "crumbs.com" and "catfood.net." The list acts as a brochure to attract customers to a specific hosting business. Reseller hosting companies often own their own domain names, such as "webhosting

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the annual rate of infant mortality has been rising for the past four years, including in north central Massachusetts.
Additionally, the disparity in infant mortality between different racial/ethnic groups continues to widen, as well as between levels of educational attainment and place of residence, the data shows. In Massachusetts, the annual rate of infant mortality was highest among native families and highest among families in two counties. It was also highest in those counties – Bristol and Hampden – that experience the highest levels of deprivation.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as “mesenchymal stem cells” detected a problem inside the body before it even became a problem. This happens before cancer has a chance to publically rebuke the rest of the body by furiously devouring thousands of cancer cells before anyone else knows the intruders have entered.
Because the cell was destroyed before it reached cancerous status, preventative treatment targets normal, healthy tissue. This reduces collateral damage.
Ironically, the cell may eventually trick cancer cells into replicating their expired kin by creating large amounts of DNA designed to go head-to-head with invasive cancer. It’s Day The Dead meets the original dead ends of the cycle. Recorded four million years of history does not suggest that this approach works well in elephants.

Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and carting at a time when prices for gas and fertilizer are rising. It also is a wonderful way to save natural resources like time and trees.
At the same time, composting helps balance large-scale land management elements that produce excess needs for air, rain, sunlight, heat, moisture and carbon; important environmental elements that, without careful management, create imbalances in nature that affect all life.
Even better, composting turns something many view as a waste product into something many view as a natural byproduct of life that replenishes the life cycle.
So, beyond saving time, money and trees, composting benefits us directly as ordinary gardeners by supplying rototiller spades full of mulch to plants. In Vermont, for example, the average farmer will generate about 15 tons of kitchen garbage annually. That material which wouldn’t otherwise fertilize plants — that another municipality will

Why is lean accounting necessary in the supply chain?
Knowing how to manage your finances is important for any business. If you aren't tracking your money properly, for example, your business could suffer in a variety of notable and unnoticeable ways. You're basically throwing good cash after bad when you aren't tracking those cash flows properly.
"The reality is lean."
For instance, weak decisions may lead to a lack of investment in some worthy projects. If you aren't diligent with tracking your finances, it's more likely you will fail to make a case that those investments make sense. You may limit some of the insights that lean accounting can represent versus a traditional accounting system. It can allow you to help your organization excel in its operations. You can see how your supply chain stands, as well as your place within that supply chain, and that can lead to a business that runs more profitably.

Odds are you've watched your favorite show on Netflix enough times to pick up on the overarching plot no matter what episode you're watching. Of course, you can manually choose an episode at "random," but the show will always resample from the plot to give you about 20 seconds of false randomness followed by a four or five minute stretch of the plot in action.
Or so it would seem. Professional biomechanical engineer Zack Burton dug into these buffet movies and uncovered something incredible. Burton, a software developer who runs miharko, remarked that the Netflix algorithm seems to have such independence from the initial menu selection, it can be assumed to map programs to infinite and unseen number of inventories. This leaves the potential for near complete randomness as long as there aren't enough individuals revisiting the menu to eject any actually random elements.

Which Irish names are making a comeback?
For the fifth year in a row, Emily was the most popular female baby name in Ireland in 2015. Emily finished the year ahead of Emma, Ava, Lily and Aisling in terms of individual popularity, according to stats from CSO figures published last month.
But while the name hasn’t fallen out of favour since Sunday Times Ireland first introduced its own All Ireland top ten list for the most popular baby names in 2011, there are several baby girls names closer to the top from a decade ago that are beginning to make a climb in 2016. Hannah, the 2011 and 2012 number-one female name in Ireland, has fallen dramatically in popularity since then, potentially an effect of the growing popularity of the new number-one – Emily. Hannah slipped to positions 64 overall and 73 for the first name.

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals in predictive analysis by allowing the rendering of an outlook based on the most likely and conceivable outcomes. This tool is a simple but effective way to display a range of possibilities.
Decision trees are visual representations of possible sequences that may occur given certain information. It can range on a spectrum, such as the Washington Post editorial board’s analysis of the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade agreement. Rumors, limited information and agenda have driven each of the nations involved to various negotiating approaches, and the possible outcomes (U.S. stays involved or leaves trade agreement) become mapped out using a diagram of a tree in list format, as it is used for decision trees. As each nation moves from one round to the next, the decisions made by the nations are noted and outlined. This reveals each reaction rather than reactions occurring in sequence and timing the actions simply allows for an understanding of the repercussions

Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered down a mountain in Hpakant, the northern state of Kachin on Friday, bringing houses down with it. Myanmar has hundreds of such illegal mines over what is estimated to be the world’s biggest source of lower-quality jade, worth around $800 million in a trade that has become an important source of financing for a country facing an outbreak of the coronavirus.
Small groups of armed militiamen guard the entrances of the non-government mines in a trade critics call an illegal taxation regime for the windfall of government-own-only quarries exempt for military exploitation. Most workers are migrants, mainly from ethnically-based neighbouring countries, with Thais the biggest group, with up to 80,000 according to one unverified report.

Four oil spill sites in Nigeria identified by the UN, which Shell has claimed to have had cleaned up by contractors since 2011, are still polluted, says a report by Amnesty.
One of the contaminated locations is Bodo, an area of swamps and creeks where ecologists have found ‘extensive areas of heavy hydrocarbon contamination’.
Amnesty visited sites in Niger Delta, an area prone flooding and having land taken up by large, multinational exploitation companies, and found that Ben Temaga, one of the most difficult areas to reach after flooding in 2015, has had an oil impact, with oilfish being discovered there, as well as domestic animals and local people.
Liz McClimans of the group’s environment plan told the BBC: ‘We went there three years ago and we were given assurances the work was finished. It was by Shell’s consultants.’
‘It was baffling. Other communities cleaned quickly, had clothes washed afterwards and were out and cleaning. In Bodo nothing was done.’

Everyone went nuts for Adobe’s “content-aware fill” in Photoshop when it came out. The boring-sounding feature is in fact an incredibly useful tool, essentially an AI-powered clone stamp. It works like clone stamp except the source image doesn’t necessarily have to be nearby: a single pixel next to a field of grass, for example, can fill a much larger area with similarly textured strands of grass. It can fill potholes in a road, for example. It was cool-ish back then. Now, as Adobe has a new Content-Aware Crop AI, it is a very different fantastical devoted to filling in your print documents correctly for you. It’s almost as if Adobe’s (PDF/AI) Feaure Engine turned into Skynet.

The Waste Land as an iPad app demonstrates how we might re-imagine the book, but it also illustrates how editorial choices can limit value.
The Guardian recently documented a June trek of 25 people through T.S. Eliot’s famous poem, The Waste Land, as part of an OU investigative group, the LARK BiblioTech. It was inspired by an interesting study that found that, for many common tasks, the iPad outperforms the MacBook. I don’t say that to mock iPad apps, because the Wasteland demo for iPad uses a range of interactivity that suggests it would mirror the experience of reading (with added fruit flies). For sure, it would look different to a published eBook.
But there’s an interesting irony: It was itself inspired by an interesting academic study. It’s thus a prototype of an app that attempts to really put an interactivity revolution into practice. But what if it hewed more to a printed version of the Wasteland: what would it need to do differently?

Longevity is a major reason why annuities have this long period of fixed payments. On October 30, a major new report on the impact of Marcellus Shale gas development on water resources will be issued. Water Resource Reporting and Water Footprint from Marcellus Shale Development in West Virginia and Pennsylvania, prepared for West Virginia’s Water Research Institute and funded by the Rockefeller family charitable funds and Dominion Resources, draws on AECOM’s expertise in water footprinting. It explores the question, How much water does natural gas drilling use and what is the potential impact of Marcellus Shale gas on the region’s surface and groundwater supplies. The Marcellus Shale natural gas formations extends across the Appalachian region and is estimated to contain 500 trillion cubic feet of technically recoverable natural gas, as much as three times the reserves of the world-wide offshore petroleum industry and as much as twenty five times the values of Shell, BP and Total combined. Both Pennsylvania and West Virginia are exploring plans currently under development whereby they could become significant suppliers of the Marcellus Stoppers who are beginning to export liquified natural gas. A move to Fridays is rarely a good sign for a TV show, which was the case for Raising Hope last fall. So while it's certainly disappointing news that the series has been cancelled by Fox, it's hardly unexpected.
Raising Hope was a very nice addition for Fox last season, perhaps not even earning out its 3.15 million viewers per episode, but the promotion last fall was very likely a death knell from the outset. Between Raising Hope, MOnday Night Football and Glee, Fox had admirably resisted the temptation to go high on comedy earlier in the evening. That ended last fall, perhaps over the Fox network's head, and eventually that led to Raising Hope and other shows improving. Perhaps someday someone will figure out that promoting an hour of programming in a timeslot immediately following the NFL always presents flaws that cannot be fixed with increased advertising. Either way, one of TV's lesser comedies got its DVR button, and that's what happens to shows on Fox.

The Czech antivirus company has been sold multiple times, but Steckler insists the change of ownership from private equity firm General Atlantic to Summit Partners will help it take the fight to major cybersecurity rivals like SentinelOne and CrowdStrike.

The sculptor Richard Houghton and service users at Tyddyn Môn, the centre run by Care & Support West Wales, and with involvement from six of the region's colleges, are creating an outdoor installation out of sustainably manufactured design and recycled materials. TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran has begun uranium enrichment at a new underground site well protected from possible airstrikes, a leading hardline newspaper reported Sunday.
Kayhan daily, which is close to Iran’s military and conservative political establishment, reported that the first step was taking 356 uranium-filled centrifuge machines out of the unknown site to a facility used for enrichment. The paper used military terms such as “chromium enrichment,” “aware” and that the report is “forbidden.”
The development follows a series of reversals in recent days by Iran in its latest nuclear dispute, which involves both Tehran’s tighter centrifuge enrichment of uranium — the heart of the Iranian nuclear program — and its tightening of the “buffers” needed to allow the following step in this chain: using the uranium for advanced reactions of uranium-209.

The mayor tried to rush through a complicated proposal that caught too many Kansas City leaders by surprise. James enthusiastically presented his broad outline to the Kansas City Council with the hope of getting his proposal on the November ballot. He was met primarily by surprise, and that same element of surprise bubbled back to the top elections only weeks after nearly 60 percent of Kansas City voters delivered James a 64-point victory in the mayoral election.
The balance and the timing of the election did fail to offer anyone the leeway to publicly evaluate the city’s financial situation or analyze the city’s set of problems in the same way the city’s government worked in similar fashion up to the mayor’s administration. James focused his campaign on ending corruption in Missouri and wanted to empower Kansas Citians to have greater oversight of city government. In other words, James and others were surprised at a deficit ballooning not just around the state but around the city. Among other issues, the city’s roadmap is a roadmap to prosperity just as many downtown institutions are back teething and burgeoning in momentum and demand for workspace.

By combining three different tools – artificial intelligence, precision oncology and metabolomics – they hope to help hospitals accurately customize treatments. Bani Asadi is a microbiologist by education, receiving a doctorate in biochemistry from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in 2016. In addition, she was a lecturer of biology until August 2019.

It turns out to be a question fraught with anxiety and mystery, just like Doyle . . . and his famous creation. Balkan Bistro and Bar, formerly the Balkan Bakery in the space demolished to make way for the Waterhouse project on Water Street, celebrated a grand opening in the former Under the Roof furniture store at 15 West Main Street, Summit, New Jersey. This restaurant, bar and nightclub is a profoundly different enterprise than the Empire Café at that address that Balkan was for many years. It becomes part of the growing micro-scene of increasing numbers of restaurants that, unlike the restaurants of their predecessors, cater to single people who live in or spend much time in Summit. It’s not a coincidence that the wine bar complements its much earlier established predecessor, Wine Works, that opened a short distance away on Springfield Avenue in Union a few years ago. Both have something to do with Summit starting to turn into something that it never entirely has been ever since the real estate boom of 1993.
One thing that Balkan has going for it is that two of the owners and occupants of the space previously had licenses to sell alcohol for the establishment that closed down.

What gives? According to data collated by Citigroup Research, net inflows into Asian funds have been relatively low at $2.1 billion (Rs9,828 crore today) since August. In the same period a year ago, the flows were a soaring Rs81,553 crore. Investors do not seem to be warming up so easily despite political dispensations across Asia being more settled than before. Investments in offshore markets in West Asia and Europe are growing. This can be partly explained by analysts who continue to look for relative value in this region to attract fund flows. Most analysts are piling up their money in green bonds and other corporate bonds issued by overseas financial institutions and governments. There are no market triggers for shifting into emerging markets in a big way from US mutual funds. Fund managers say mandates from US investment managers continue to seek certainty in long-term returns from emerging markets. Thanks to ever more sophisticated technology, it is much easier to obtain data - and to analyze it - than was thought possible even a few years ago. As a result, there is an understandable feeling that decision-making in organizations can be done much better because of that. In reality, this is a misunderstanding of the fundamental difference between "data" and "information." While it is without doubt true that data sets are growing larger by leaps and bounds, such forward progress shouldn't be the goal. In actual practice, the proportion of reliable data sets (information) compared to unreliable data sets (simple observations) remains small.
I agree that it is ultimately all about how one then proceeds to make a decision. Still, most companies put their money not on predictive models but on improving the availability and quality of the comparison base. The constant demand for data feeding the "near-thorough analysis by data evaluation" mood only leads to disappointment - and renewed demand for "new models" - expect to discover "2017 models" seven years from now.

While in Queensland the use of animal recognition technology is being used to conserve water, on the east coast a new system of unrolling vegetable strip corridors has been trialled.

A Los Angeles-bound Alaska Airlines flight was forced to return to Seattle's airport Monday afternoon after an airport worker fell asleep and became trapped in the cargo hold.
Alaska Airlines said the flight had stopped in Seattle momentarily for a tech check, then push back and take off so it could proceed to LA. On the plane, passengers said the crew suddenly realized a worker was missing. They called for help and the pilot and flight attendants left the passengers and went in search of the missing person. This person was found, and had become trapped in the cargo hold. It's not known if he fell, and died, during a nap. The airline said everyone remained calm during the ordeal, perhaps by watching television sets personnel issued as cabin bugleries for an Emmy's broadcast later that night. There were 145 passengers on board, including 43 without tickets who had gone for an airport tour. No injuries were sustained, other than to the airline worker. Two news helicopters were also aboard. The NTSB has been contacted.

While cybersecurity should be a year-round concern for small business owners, income tax filing season can bring some particular risks, according to the IRS.
The agency says it has gotten an increase in reports of phone and email scams involving the agency that try to trick businesses and their employees into paying excess taxes or identity thieves taking over tax returns before they are completed for tax season. Other scams also have risen in recent years, such as computer malware attacks installing a key logger that captures passwords. Separate IRS cybersecurity guidance has also warned businesses about various Android and Apple apps with finance-related features that included codes for malware libraries.
Because of the tax season, the IRS, as always, says businesses should increase their awareness and protection from potential cybersecurity threats, including by installing additional layers of defense by analyzing cybersecurity risks that affect your data ecosystem.

There is no easy option for Northern Ireland after Brexit.
Deciding on post-Brexit border arrangements between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic is becoming an issue for which the phrase "the devil is in the detail" could well have been coined. To describe these arrangements is very complicated; to try to explain why some arrangements are unacceptable is fiendishly complex.
This much is for certain. It will not be possible to maintain the free movement of people across, or in, the Irish Republic unless the next generation of Northern Ireland is allowed to know Irish of the same quality shared by people in the Irish Republic, Northern Ireland and mainland parts of the United Kingdom. It means requires a generation of young people who could just as easily live and learn in Birmingham or in London as in Belfast and Dublin. It means, for newer people from a range of national traditions who may have some familiarity with traditional Irish language, that they must be able to make use of the opportunity to learn Irish. It means, further, seeks compatibility between Northern Ireland and Ireland which allow free movement to develop to a point where learning the traditional language is a priority, as in the Republic

Many in the media and tech industry see Uber’s decision to sell its Chinese business unit to rival Didi Chuxing as a failure for the U.S. ride-hailing giant. It’s easy to believe that Uber failed in China, but the real news is on what it meant for the Chinese market in its wake. Chinese businesses in digital transportation space have seen their valuations soar in light of the news of Uber’s exit. Already, the news of the acquisition is helping RenRen, the Facebook equivalent in China, see its shares increase by 6.5 percent. After all, Didi Chuxing has already claimed some of the most tech savvy Chinese customers. In the wake of the acquisition, Didi said that rides on the service will increase from 65 billion to 105 billion trips a year. It could almost be considered as #weneedUber in China. Uber’s market share is now seven times larger and has a 36-40 percent share. Didi is now the top ride-sharing company in China with 65 billion trips

Plans are gathering pace for Bradford’s new City Library with the arrival of a new temporary children’s library in City Park today.
The opening of the new Park and Read facility coincides with National Bookstart Week, the annual celebration of books and reading for children under five years old.
The library will feature games, story-times and book-displays aimed at attracting children, including fun comics drawn by students from a local art college, an on-location book mark maker, games console area and activities for teens.
It is one of a series of initiatives aimed at inspiring Bradford’s residents to celebrate libraries. It follows National Libraries Day earlier this month, the 40th Bradford Literature Festival being held in March, and a not-for-profit belated 150th birthday party for the city’s libraries last month.
The creation of the new library in City Park is part of the Council’s £1m Refresh project for libraries globally and is made possible through the support of the Heritage Lottery Fund. It will use volunteers from the public and local schools and colleges

Smoking Ban Hurting Small Taverns?
Lawyers for Colorado bar owners say the eight-week-old statewide smoking ban has devastated some smaller taverns, slashing their incomes by up to 40 percent over the past several months. "I know a lot of hairdressers that take horrible pleas," Glen Betz, an Alamosa bar and liquor store owner, told radio station KRCC. "Well, make the smoking part of the haircut."
Betz said business was down between 30 and 40 percent since the smoking ban and that he had to cut three part-time hours for each of the one-shift employees who worked for him. "Word travels pretty fast around town," he said. "I wish I had done it sooner." Betz said he wasn't optimistic that smoking restrictions would go away, because he believes a large number of restaurants and drinking establishments bought nicotine vaporizers, the smoking machines that look like waterproof suitcases. The focus of the series is on the progress we need to make in order to have a world-class education system for all of our children. Invariably in this conversation and others about education policy, what is at stake lines up directly along household income and family wealth lines. The consequences of the past and present – and what President Barack Obama calls “the choices our suite” in the next decade or decade and a half – hinge in no small part on the level of investment we make in education, our children’s future and in each other.

John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
[NEW YORK] John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
The upgrades include the removal of aging Terminal One and turning it into a giant station for an expanded AirTrain system, Andrew Cuomo said in a press conference.
The AirTrain system provides passengers with rapid transit to all terminals. It currently only extends a few airplane-lengths down its single center line and covers only the main terminal complex.
An expansion is also expected to include an airport train service to various locations in the city and connectivity with the city's transportation systems.
Construction on the airport upgrade began on Tuesday.

NEW YORK — For a second year in a row, the NFL will air a dramatic PSA during the Super Bowl addressing the issue of domestic violence.
This year’s video shows a succession of text messages between two friends — one of whom has been injured by an intimate partner. After initially sticking up for his friend, the other seems to cancel plans out of embarrassment over supporting an abusive relationship. Harold Varner of the Saks 5th Avenue Foundation, an advocate for women’s health and welfare, and former NFL players Vince Papale and D’Brickashaw Ferguson anchored the PSA production with Ese Funds to support those affected by domestic violence.
Both have been affected first hand — Kapernick’s mother Nicole was a victim of domestic violence in 2011 — and other high-profile athletes will likely join them in educating fans on the subject. Lilly will save about $731,666 over 10 years, to further encourage the multimillion dollar renovation of the city-block-wide property.
Lilly spent about $11.7 million starting in 2011 to restore Anslee to accommodate the team’s needs.
Lilly, which owns the complex, will own the plaza for many of the amenities it creates, such as loft apartments, restaurants, entertainment facilities, visitors meeting areas, plaza level retail and community event facilities.

In what has come to pass, a large Haitian electorate continues to believe in the Duvaliers and their legacy, yet demands for an end to their continued leadership were predominant in a fragile coalition opposed to Duvalier's invading Haiti with his military in late April. In the aftermath of revelations of continued rampant corruption among the military hierarchy, the political rhetoric surrounding Duvalier's status yielded status quo results.
